child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: This dialect name is applied to immigrants in the United States. It is heavily influences from Russian Church Slavonic, and is centered in Pittsburg. It is based on Eastern Slovak dialects with West Ukrainian.

child.pub-comments: Standard Ukrainian is based upon these dialects, and used to be primarily a religious tool, and developed largely in the sixteenth century
child.geography: Spoken east of the approximate line Xvastiv-Balta

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Ukrainian used to be forbidden in Russia, which is why it is sometimes referred to as 'Little Russian', the moniker by which it was called when even the term 'Ukrainian' was forbidden.
child.geography: Spoken primarily in the Ukraine

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8

child.geography: Spoken in the northern Belarus area, near Latvia

child.pub-comments: Traditionally, only two dialect groups are favored: Central and Transitional Belorussian.

child.geography: Spoken in a wide band across the central Belorussian area

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken in southwestern area, near Ukraine and Poland

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: When the Russians fell under the Tartar yoke, it allowed a long period of political separation, creating Belarus.
child.geography: Belorussian developed from the descendants of ancient East Slavonic tribes which inhabited the territory between the rivers Pripyat and Western Dvina in the upper reaches of the Dnepr and along the Sozh.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8

Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Russian dialects were differentiated during the Kievian Empire, and dialects were based upon languages spoke in individual outposts. However, after the breakup of the Kievian Empire due to the Mongol invasion, the dialects became eroded by the penetrating Muscovite influence.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Based upon the Muscovite dialect of Peter the Great; there is a huge gulf between vernacular Russian and Literary Russian, but no more than is expected in other societies

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken by 137 million ethnic Russians in the former Soviet Union; of the 125 million people of other ethnic groups, 16 million claim Russian and their first language, and an additional 61 million declare themselves to be functional in Russian.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8

Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: The Standard Slovak is based upon the Central Slovak dialect. The Slovak-speaking youth are fighting its development and stabilization, mainly in the form of Czech forms and foreign borrowing.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Standard Slovak was based upon this dialect.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: This dialect shares similar features to adjacent Moravian dialects of Czech.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken in the Slovak Republic (or the eastern part of Czechoslovakia), as well as by another half-million people in the Czech Republic.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken in northeast Moravia

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Standard Czech is a semi-artificial creation archaic in many respects, while the vernacular has continued to evolve since the norms were set.' (455)

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken in Bohemia

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken in southeast Moravia

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.geography: Spoken in central Moravia

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: These dialects are transitional between the Standard Czech and Commonly Spoken Czech.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: There is a consequent tension between the modern literary language and the spoken Czech, usually known as Common Czech, in which natural development has culminated. This has its own distinctive morphology, relatively impoverished syntactic variation, and a lexicon, and in part syntax, that reveals the influence of German.' (455)

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Due to emigration, most Czech dialects are less cohesive and less resistant to the host environment; however, some communities with continuity of evolution before the First World War are linguistically undamaged. Also, the written version of Czech is based upon the variant spoke in Prague.
child.geography: Spoken in the provinces of Bohemia, Moravia and the southern part of Silesia

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8

Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: This dialect is considered Standard Sorbian, the literary language.

Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Many Sorbian speech communities are based upon their denominational following; more than half are Lutherans, about a quarter are Catholics and others have no denominational allegiance.
child.geography: Sorbian has no precisely define speech boundaries, natural or otherwise.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Polabian dialects are represented by different scholars who studied them, and ths had different hypotheses concerning sound changes.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Polabian dialects are represented by different scholars who studied them, and ths had different hypotheses concerning sound changes.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Polabian dialects are represented by different scholars who studied them, and ths had different hypotheses concerning sound changes.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Most Polabian grammar is speculative due to inconsistencies and conflicting hypotheses, especially in the phonology.
child.geography: Spoken by the Slavonic tribe living on the left bank of the Elbe River

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Most Polish speakers speak both a dialect and the Standard language equally well.
child.geography: Spoken in northern Poland

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Most Polish speakers speak both a dialect and the Standard language equally well.
child.geography: Spoken in southern Poland

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Most Polish speakers speak both a dialect and the Standard language equally well.
child.geography: Spoken in northeastern Poland

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Literary Polish had to compete with Latin largely during it's development as well as Czech, due to Catholicism coming to Poland from Bohemia.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: This dialect was an attempt to create a literary language based on Polish and Czech dialects.

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Most Polish speakers speak both a dialect and the Standard language equally well.
child.geography: Spoken in southeastern Poland

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Most Polish speakers speak both a dialect and the Standard language equally well.
child.geography: Spoken in northwestern Poland

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Polish belongs to the Lechitic branch of the West Slavonic group, together with the extinct dialects of the Slavs who once inhabited the area between the lower and mid Oder and Elbe Rivers. The oldest recorded Polish sentence dates from the thirteenth century and the oldest continuous text from the fourteenth century.' (686) The Second World War has reduced the number of dialects and dialectal variations.
child.geography: Spoken in Poland and the former Soviet Union

child.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
child.pub-comments: Some consider Cassubian merely a Polish dialect; however, this raises questions about Cassubian nationality. No attempt at standardizing Cassubian has been successful.
child.geography: Spoken in a band of territory to the west, northwet and southwest of Gdańsk

child.pub-comments: Old Church Slavonic is the language extrapolated from a small corpus of probably late tenth century copies, mainly of translations made about a century earlier of Greek ecclesiastical texts.' (125) There exist later texts which may not be necessarily classified as Old Church Slavonic, but rather as 'Church Slavonic'. Many texts contain Balkan dialectal features.

root.publications: Comrie, Bernard & Greville G. Corbett (eds.). 2002. The Slavonic Languages, Paperback edn. London: Routledge. ISBN 0-415-28078-8
root.pub-comments: Unlike Latin, the parent of the Romance languages, Proto-Slavic was not recorded. This family's languages are spoke in eastern Europe and western Asia. 'The Slavs were the last Indo-Europeans to appear in the annals of history. Slavonic texts were not recorded till the middle of the ninth century and the first definite reference to the Slav's arrival on the frontiers of the civilized world dates from the sxith century AD, when the Slavs struck out upon their conquest of central and south-eastern Europe.' (62)
